Not being normat isn't a bad thing either. For example if I rank in the top 5% of net worth in the USA, I am not normal. I'm exceptional and that is a good thing. Message.Title: Question about the meaning of "liberal"
Message.Msg: Here is the etymology of the word "liberal" liberal (adj.) mid-14c., "generous," also, late 14c., "selfless; noble, nobly born; abundant," and, early 15c., in a bad sense "extravagant, unrestrained," from Old French liberal "befitting free men, noble, generous, willing, zealous" (12c.), from Latin liberalis "noble, gracious, munificent, generous," lit. "of freedom, pertaining to or befitting a free man," from liber "free, unrestricted, unimpeded; unbridled, unchecked, licentious," from PIE *leudh-ero- (cf. Greek eleutheros "free"), probably originally "belonging to the people" (though the precise semantic development is obscure), and a suffixed form of the base *leudh- "people" (cf. Old Church Slavonic ljudu, Lithuanian liaudis, Old English leod, German Leute "nation, people;" Old High German liut "person, people") but literally "to mount up, to grow." With the meaning "free from restraint in speech or action," liberal was used 16c.-17c. as a term of reproach. It revived in a positive sense in the Enlightenment, with a meaning "free from prejudice, tolerant," which emerged 1776-88. Many of the people on this board who consider themselves liberal seem to me to often be the ones who are most against personal freedoms. They are the ones that want more regulations and controls over people. The liberals I grew up with never trusted government and wanted less government less laws. They were always promoting freedom from government and "Power to the people". Now it seems that liberalism has been debased by modern faux liberalism that favors more government control and less personal freedoms. Where did the modern liberal lose his way and fall victim to being a willing collectivist government controlled dupe?

Topic.Title: Question about the meaning of "liberal"

Message.Msg: Originally, there were people who preferred a 'liberal' interpretation of the Constitution, as opposed to those who adopted a 'conservative' interpretation of the Constitution.
